lead_paragraph: Everything becomes a shorter version of itself. Essays become op-eds. Op-eds become blog posts. Blog posts become Twitter tweets. The Sidney Awards stand athwart technology, yelling stop. They are awarded every year to some of the best examples of long-form journalism and thought. The first Sidney goes to Michael Lewis, whose essay ''The End'' appeared in Portfolio magazine. Lewis often writes about people who can see reality clearly while the rest of humanity is lost in a fog of delusion. He describes Meredith Whitney and Steve Eisman, two financial analysts who understood early on that the U.S. financial system had turned into a doomsday machine. Whitney announced early on that Citigroup was in a ton of trouble. Eisman stood up in the middle of a speech by a mortgage company C.E.O. to tell him that his default rates were about to become astronomical.

headline.main: The Sidney Awards

abstract: David Brooks Op-Ed column announces winners of Sidney Awards, honor Brooks created to designate his estimation of best magazine essays of year; winners include Michael Lewis, Christopher Caldwell and John Judis; Brooks describes winning essays (M)
snippet: As essays become op-eds and op-eds become blog posts, the Sidney Awards, which recognize long-form journalism and thought, stand athwart technology, yelling stop.

lead_paragraph: In a raucous sendoff at a church on this city's South Side, Roland W. Burris, the contested appointee for the Senate seat vacated by President-elect Barack Obama, vowing on Sunday night to cordially but aggressively fight efforts to block him from joining the chamber when he arrives in Washington this week. Senate leaders have said they intend to prevent the seating of Mr. Burris, given his appointment last week by this state's embattled governor, Rod R. Blagojevich. Senator Harry Reid, the majority leader, said on Sunday that the Senate had the legal right to bar Mr. Burris from the new session, which begins Tuesday.

lead_paragraph: Horse racing's most famous sibling is about to get his first test. The bay colt Nicanor, the full brother to Barbaro, is nearing his debut, an occasion that will begin to answer a question that has hovered over him since shortly after his birth: Will he, too, be a star? According to his trainer, Michael Matz, who also trained Barbaro, Nicanor should be ready for his first race by late January or early February and will begin his career at Gulfstream Park in Hallandale Beach, Fla. Matz is not sure how good the 3-year-old Nicanor will be, but he is optimistic that he has a bright future.

headline.main: First Race Draws Near For Barbaro's Brother

snippet: The bay colt Nicanor, the full brother to Barbaro, who was euthanized in 2007, will be ready for his first race later this month or next. Will he, too, be a star?

lead_paragraph: The Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn proposed Monday to close at least 14 of its elementary schools as part of a reorganization that officials said they hoped would stem a steady decline in enrollment that has plagued Catholic school systems nationwide for decades.This would be the second major round of elementary school closings in recent years for the diocese, which comprises Brooklyn and Queens. In 2005, it closed 25, and in the next two years, seven more. If the proposed closings are carried out, the diocese will have shut down nearly one-third of the elementary schools it had just half a decade ago.

lead_paragraph: The Diocese of Brooklyn has proposed closing 14 elementary schools at the end of the current academic year, a plan that would mean that one of the nation's largest Catholic dioceses would have shuttered nearly 40 percent of its grade schools in the past seven years. The proposed closings and mergers, announced on Monday, are the latest retrenchment for a school system that was once a bedrock of neighborhood stability, and a magnet for families of many creeds and homelands seeking safe, reliable education at a relatively modest cost.

lead_paragraph: Three generations of Thompsons gathered around the patriarch's dining room table in Brooklyn Heights the other day and gave three varied perspectives on the inauguration of Barack Obama. This prominent black political family from Brooklyn is headed by Harlem-born William C. Thompson. Known as Willie, he is 84 and served in a segregated infantry unit in Italy during World War II. His father worked for a furniture store, was a city marshal and remembered hearing Marcus Garvey preach his Back to Africa gospel on a Harlem street corner.

headline.main: A Historic Moment, Through One Prominent Brooklyn Family's Perspective

snippet: Three generations of Thompsons gathered in Brooklyn Heights and gave three varied perspectives on the inauguration of Barack Obama.

lead_paragraph: BARACK OBAMA'S victory in November demonstrated, to the surprise of many Americans and much of the world, that we were ready to see a black man as president. Of course, we had seen several black presidents already, not in the real White House but in the virtual America of movies and television. The presidencies of James Earl Jones in ''The Man,''Morgan Freeman in ''Deep Impact,''Chris Rock in ''Head of State'' and Dennis Haysbert in ''24'' helped us imagine Mr. Obama's transformative breakthrough before it occurred. In a modest way, they also hastened its arrival. Make no mistake: Hollywood's historic refusal to embrace black artists and its insistence on racist caricatures and stereotypes linger to this day. Yet in the past 50 years -- or, to be precise, in the 47 years since Mr. Obama was born -- black men in the movies have traveled from the ghetto to the boardroom, from supporting roles in kitchens, liveries and social-problem movies to the rarefied summit of the Hollywood A-list. In those years the movies have helped images of black popular life emerge from behind what W. E. B. Du Bois called ''a vast veil,'' creating public spaces in which we could glimpse who we are and what we might become.

headline.main: How the Movies Made a President

snippet: Evolving cinematic roles have prepared America to have a black man in charge.

multimedia.credit: A look at how various types of black roles in film have helped lead to having a black man in charge.

lead_paragraph: What F. Scott Fitzgerald called the ''fresh, green breast of the New World'' that greeted Henry Hudson 400 years ago has been reimagined by a senior ecologist at the Wildlife Conservation Society. Drawing on 18th-century British military maps, the ecologist, Eric W. Sanderson, has painstakingly recreated Manhattan's rolling landscape -- Mannahatta in an American Indian dialect meant ''island of many hills,'' many of which were all but leveled when the street grid was imposed in the 19th century -- that Hudson encountered.

lead_paragraph: For months, theatergoers have clamored for new blood on Broadway, and now they're going to get it. The Nederlander Organization said in a statement that it had acquired the rights to produce a musical based on the Michael Jackson album "Thriller" and its groundbreaking video, in which the King of Pop transforms into a werewolf while he's on a date. The production will feature songs from the "Thriller" album as well as Mr. Jackson's record "Off the Wall." Mr. Jackson is expected to participate in the musical's creation. In a statement, James L. Nederlander, the president of the Nederlander Organization, said, "I love the idea of making 'Thriller' a musical. Girl meets boy, they fall in love, boy has big secret, now what..." A creative team for "Thriller the Musical" was not announced.

lead_paragraph: John Updike, the kaleidoscopically gifted writer whose quartet of Rabbit Angstrom novels highlighted so vast and protean a body of fiction, verse, essays and criticism as to place him in the first rank of American men of letters, died on Tuesday. He was 76 and lived in Beverly Farms, Mass. The cause was cancer, according to a statement by Alfred A. Knopf, his publisher. A spokesman said Mr. Updike died at a hospice outside Boston.

headline.main: John Updike, a Lyrical Writer of the Ordinary, Is Dead at 76

lead_paragraph: John Updike, the kaleidoscopically gifted writer whose quartet of Rabbit novels highlighted a body of fiction, verse, essays and criticism so vast, protean and lyrical as to place him in the first rank of American authors, died on Tuesday in Danvers, Mass. He was 76 and lived in Beverly Farms, Mass. The cause was cancer, according to a statement by Knopf, his publisher. A spokesman said Mr. Updike had died at the Hospice of the North Shore in Danvers.

headline.main: John Updike, a Lyrical Writer of the Middle-Class Man, Dies at 76

abstract: John Updike, author whose four Rabbit novels highlighted body of fiction, verse, essays and criticism so vast and lyrical as to place him in first rank of American authors, dies at age 76; placed his best-known protagonist Harry Rabbit Angstrom against background of last half-century's major events, found his subject in everyday dramas of marriage, sex and divorce and wrote about America with boundless curiosity and wit in careful and attentive prose; his writing inspired two schools of thought: those who responded to his descriptive prose as sensuous engagement with world and those who argued that it was more style than content; photos (L)

lead_paragraph: UPDATE: A lawyer for John Landis has told The Associated Press that he would sue to stop production of the "Thriller" musical if necessary. In a statement, James L. Nederlander said, "I'm confident that these past differences can be worked out."ORIGINAL POST: Having filmed Michael Jackson dancing in a graveyard, the filmmaker John Landis now seeks to bring the King of Pop somewhere equally as frightening: a court of law. Last week, Mr. Landis, the director and co-writer of the video for Mr. Jackson's "Thriller," filed suit against Mr. Jackson for unpaid profits from the video and a making-of documentary, Variety reported. The suit, filed in Los Angeles County Superior Court, says that for the past four years Mr. Jackson and his company Optimum Productions have failed to pay Mr. Landis money he is owed from these film projects or to account for the profits. On Monday, the Nederlander Organization announced that it had acquired the rights to produce a musical based on "Thriller" and its video, an homage to horror movies in which Mr. Jackson turns into a werewolf and a zombie.

headline.main: Horrors! Lawsuit Filed Over 'Thriller' Video

abstract: John Landis, the director and co-writer of the video for Michael Jackson's "Thriller," filed for unpaid profits from the video and a making-of documentary.

lead_paragraph: The halftime show at the Super Bowl is just one more big gig for Bruce Springsteen. The Boss has rocked Giants Stadium 19 times. That is more than a full regular season of Giants and Jets home games combined. lead_paragraph: The Insider is a recurring profile of emerging tastemakers in the fields of fashion, design, food, travel and the arts. Here Christina Tosi, pastry chef for Momofuku Milk Bar (as well as the rest of the Momofuku eateries), shares a few of her essentials. Tosi, an alumna of WD-50 and Bouley, is known for her inspired interpretations of sweet treats, such as something called the Compost Cookie (its ingredients include potato chips, pretzels and coffee grounds) and a milk drink infused with cereal.

headline.main: The Insider | Christina Tosi

abstract: The Insider is a recurring profile of emerging tastemakers in the fields of fashion, design, food, travel and the arts. Here Christina Tosi, pastry chef for Momofuku Milk Bar (as well as the rest of the Momofuku eateries), shares a few of her essentials. Tosi, an alumna of WD-50 and Bouley, is known for her inspired interpretations of sweet treats, such as something called the Compost Cookie (its ingredients include potato chips, pretzels and coffee grounds) and a milk drink infused with cereal.Name: Christina TosiAge: 27Occupation: I make sweets, but I hate titles.Home base: Milk Bar.Retail standby: Thrift stores, consignment shops or estate sales. The older and mustier - with the cutest old ladies - the better.Music venue: United Palace Theatre, Washington Heights.Favorite concert: Neil Young in the city. I go every year - I think most go to hear him rock out. But I go and sit quietly in my seat, sitting on my hands and waiting for everyone else to leave the stage. He hooks on his harmonica and starts stomping, swaying and crying out loud. It breaks my heart every time and I can never get enough.Music: Anything dreamy and calm, old and new - Bob Dylan every time, CocoRosie, Beach House, old My Morning Jacket.Provisions: Candy; cookies; chips, cafe bustelo on the stove; sugar; salt; caffeine.For gifts: Books, cookies and notes/letters of sincerity. But if I had it my way, I'd give a puppy in a bow tie every time.Restaurant: WD-50 for a real meal, a snack or a drink; Paul's Da Burger Joint for a burger on an English muffin, cheese fries, onion rings and a "Michael Jackson."Drink: Lately it has been stinky, sometimes barnyard-y Italian reds. When I'm nervous, it's bloody marys. Any other time, gin and tonics or negronis.Party central: My home kitchen, late at night: friends, family meals, music, mabye ranting and raving over work or an episode of "Top Chef," and a drink.Momentary style obsessions: Bow ties on my dogs; old lady jewelry; boots/tights/dresses - anything warm that feels like home.Reading material: Just started an off-the-beaten-track rotating book club with my mom and sis - I'm waiting for this month's book. In the meantime, "The Urban Homestead: Your Guide to Self-Sufficient Living in the Heart of the City," by Kelly Coyne and Erik Knutzen.Art pick: Paula Wachsstock. She is my hero and my idol. No one and nothing is better than the world seen through her eyes on canvas.Museums: When it's warm, the Socrates Sculpture Park; when it's cold, the Whitney or the Guggenheim.Movies: "Rocky" I, II and III; "Dirty Rotten Scoundrels." I watched them with my father and his best friend so often as a little girl. They still have the ability to make me laugh, make me cry and remind me of the simplest times in life for no reasons other than my own.Vacation destination: My lake house in southwest Maryland with the greatest people in the world - I never do so little, laugh so hard and have such a great time.Winter survival tip: Eat more than you should - summer is still months away; shamelessly love your winter hat (never take it off, wear it to bed!); wake up in the middle of the night during a snowfall and go for a walk on an unfettered side street - nothing is better and we all believe the city is ours alone.Something you are looking forward to this spring: Long walks late at night; fixing up the backyard; sundresses; bike rides. Christina's Lower East Side/East Village Neighborhood View Larger MapHere are some of Tosi's favorite haunts in the Lower East Side/East Village that she visits regularly. The map above is interactive; click on the blue markers to learn more about Christina's spots.The East-East Village and L.E.S. is the closest thing to being "mine." I always walk by all of our restaurants on First Avenue, through the park and then down Avenue B until it turns to Clinton Street. I want to change my path, but I just can't. P.D.T. for a drink, a hot dog and good company. Tompkins Square Park for a midday breather in good weather. I goto stalk other dog owners and their dogs, I go to watch movies in thesummer, I go to lay on blankets on fall afternoons. Sunny & Annie's for the Chicago or the Bulgogi sandwich. I will wait allday and night, walk my cold, tired self blocks over, order my sandwich (buy some chips and ice cream and candy) and lay in bed with my booty. Mama's Bar for a beer. WD~50 for a hug, or some advice, or an ingredient, or a snack, or a drink, or a three-hour meal. Essex Street Market, a great resource for interesting ingredients (slightly off the beaten path) and an amazing source of wonder and amusement.

lead_paragraph: His name is Nicanor, a name, like that of his brother, borrowed from a portrait of foxhounds proudly displayed in the home of his owners. Before he ever stepped to the starting gate Saturday afternoon at Gulfstream Park for his first race, he had spent his first three years being compared with his famous brother, Barbaro. Barbaro, Nicanor's full brother, won the 2006 Kentucky Derby and began his journey toward that title on the Gulfstream track, winning his dirt debut in the Holy Bull Stakes.

headline.main: Brother of Barbaro Falls Short in Debut

snippet: Nicanor, the brother of 2006 Kentucky Derby winner Barbaro, finished 10th in his one-mile maiden race at Gulfstream Park.

lead_paragraph: The agenda was telegraphed in Kobe Bryant's eyes, which were fixed in a cold stare Monday night, and in a taut expression that varied between hyper-serious and hyper-focused. There were no mischievous grins, the sort that Bryant often flashes between basketball magic tricks, no outward sign that he was enjoying his own history-making night at Madison Square Garden. The 1,000-watt smile only came later, 45 minutes after Bryant had wrapped up a record-breaking 61-point gem that sent the Knicks into a funk and moved the crowd to a delirious standing ovation.

headline.main: Bryant Puts on a Show, Setting Garden Records

snippet: Kobe Bryant made 19 of 31 field-goal attempts and all 20 of his foul shots for a total of 61 points as he broke scoring records for Madison Square Garden.

lead_paragraph: When two guards were accused last month of encouraging inmates in one Rikers Island jail to police themselves, leading to beatings and in one case the killing of an inmate, correction officials called the situation ''an aberration'' and said they had not seen such a case in other units involving other guards. But New York City has been sued in recent years by more than a half-dozen Rikers inmates claiming to have been the victims of beatings by prisoners while guards looked the other way, or worse, ordered the attacks. The city settled one case for $500,000, and another for just under $100,000. A new lawsuit was filed Tuesday.

headline.main: Lawsuits Suggest Pattern of Rikers Guards Looking Other Way

snippet: An episode of violence last month at the Rikers Island jail appears not to have been an isolated incident.

lead_paragraph: The leader of the hunting party carried a 12-gauge Winchester 101 repeating shotgun with a wooden stock. Standing thigh-deep in the stagnant bottoms of Willow Hole, where a Labrador retriever named Congo whimpered from a twilit hardwood's bend, she waited for first shooting light, the moment a half-hour before sunrise when hunters can legally fire on the wood ducks gliding overhead. ''Is it time yet?'' whispered one of the group's hunters, Kate Morrison, 45, from Memphis, a stay-at-home mother of two boys.

headline.main: Sorority of the Swamp

snippet: They call themselves the Swamp Witches, a half-dozen women pledged to return twice a year to the Ward Lake Hunting Club, which occupies a prime span of the Mississippi Flyway.

lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Bishop Nicholas A. DiMarzio of the Diocese of Brooklyn unveiled a proposal on Saturday to convert four Roman Catholic schools singled out for closing into public charter schools, an 11th-hour lifeline meant to preserve the education provided in the buildings and stave off potential overcrowding in city schools. It would be the first time such a plan was undertaken in New York and could serve as a model for converting other Catholic and private schools. Mr. Bloomberg framed the plan as an unlikely alliance, the product of creative thinking in a time of economic distress. He said it would ''bring stability and much-needed predictability back'' to families with children at some of the 14 schools in Brooklyn and Queens that the diocese has marked for closing at the end of the academic year because of declining enrollment and rising operating costs.

headline.main: Mayor and Bishop Announce Plan to Turn 4 Catholic Schools Into Charter Schools

snippet: The plan would save 4 of 14 parochial schools in Brooklyn and Queens, converting them to public charter schools.

They are stored here at Paumanok Vineyards to take advantage of nature's refrigeration and help crystallize the impurities, he explained.

lead_paragraph: Of all the luminaries who have received the key to the city, Capt. Chesley B. Sullenberger III is among the least likely to need reminding that being a hero, as Will Rogers once said, ''is about the shortest-lived profession on earth.'' Especially in New York, where fame can be particularly fleeting. That symbolic key can just as easily open a Pandora's box of ignominy as it can guarantee the eternal gratitude of New Yorkers. If there's no famous case of a key being rescinded, there has been more than one occasion when the city fathers wished they could change the locks.

headline.main: Advice to a Brave Pilot: Use That City Key Wisely

snippet: Capt. Chesley B. Sullenberger III and his crew were presented with the key to the city on Monday. But New Yorkers know the title “hero” is hard won and easily lost.

lead_paragraph: The announcement in church bulletins and on Web sites has been greeted with enthusiasm by some and wariness by others. But mainly, it has gone over the heads of a vast generation of Roman Catholics who have no idea what it means: ''Bishop Announces Plenary Indulgences.'' In recent months, dioceses around the world have been offering Catholics a spiritual benefit that fell out of favor decades ago -- the indulgence, a sort of amnesty from punishment in the afterlife -- and reminding them of the church's clout in mitigating the wages of sin.

headline.main: For Catholics, a Door to Absolution Is Reopened

snippet: Indulgences are available at several churches in New York City, where many have never heard of them outside history class.

lead_paragraph: Grady Jackson, a defensive tackle with the Atlanta Falcons, said he used the weight-loss capsules. Kathie Lee Gifford was enthusiastic about them on the ''Today'' show. Retailers like GNC and the Vitamin Shoppe sold them, no prescription required. But the Food and Drug Administration now says those weight-loss capsules, called StarCaps and promoted as natural dietary supplements using papaya, could be hazardous to your health. In violation of the law, the agency has found, the capsules also contained a potent pharmaceutical drug called bumetanide which can have serious side effects.

headline.main: Dangerous Secret In Diet Pills

abstract: Food and Drug Administration says weight-loss capsules called StarCaps and promoted as natural dietary supplements using papaya could be hazardous to user's health; has found capsules, in violation of law, also contain potential pharmaceutical drug called bumetanide which can have serious side effects; StarCaps are made in Peru; American distributor Balance Health Products has voluntarily withdrawn product; FDA has cited 69 tainted weight-loss supplements, including pills sold under names Sliminate, Superslim and Slim Up; agency plans to issue longer list of brands to avoid that are spiked with drugs; photos of Nikki Haskell, whose company distributed StarCaps, and Atlantic Falcons player Grady Jackson, who tested positive for bumetanide (L)
snippet: The Food and Drug Administration says the weight-loss capsules StarCaps contain a potent pharmaceutical drug called bumetanide, which can have serious side effects.

headline.main: For Catholics, a Door to Absolution Is Reopened

abstract: Roman Catholic Church is offering indulgences, amnesty from punishment for sin in afterlife, as it moves further from Second Vatican Council and toward more conservative ideology; according to church teaching, sinners who are absolved in confessional and perform penance still face punishment in Purgatory before they can enter heaven; indulgences, granted in exchange for certain prayers or pilgrimages at specific times, reduce or erase punishment with no ceremony or sacrament; purchase of indulgences was outlawed in 1567, but they can be earned through charity and other works; return of indulgences began with Pope John Paul II, who authorized bishops to offer them in 2000 as part of celebration of church's third millennium, but offers have increased markedly under Pope Benedict; one motivation for reintroducing indulgences is to get Catholics back into confession and reinvigorate idea of personal sin; photos (M)

lead_paragraph: Patrons are asked to leave their bullets at the bar in the Congolese brothel that is the setting for ''Ruined,'' the strong and absorbing new play by Lynn Nottage at the Manhattan Theater Club. Mama Nadi (Saidah Arrika Ekulona) runs a cozy little whorehouse -- one of the cleanest and safest places in the area -- and she's determined to keep it that way. That means no bullets, no brawling, no unwashed hands and no talk of the civil war being waged in the rain forest outside. But no matter how vigilant Mama is, evidence of a cruel and bloody conflict keeps trickling in, like isolated raindrops from a storm. It's not so much the sound of gunfire. Mama and her customers are used to that. It's what is in the eyes and postures of the women who work for her. Like Sophie (the exquisite Condola Rashad), Mama's 18-year-old bookkeeper and bar singer, who walks with the stiff, wide-legged gait of someone who feels pain with every step she takes.

headline.main: War's Terrors, Through a Brothel Window

snippet: Lynn Nottage’s strong and absorbing new play is a comfortable, old-fashioned drama about an uncomfortable of-the-moment subject.

lead_paragraph: The shimmering hands in the aggressively saucy new revival of ''Pippin'' at the Mark Taper Forum here are not, as you might assume, a tribute to Bob Fosse, who directed and choreographed the original Broadway production in 1972. Those wriggling digits are saying something too. The classic splayed-finger movement that has become a Fosse cliché is practically identical to the gesture used by the deaf to signify applause. It's a nifty coincidence that underscores how comfortably this beloved musical has been adapted to suit a cast of both hearing and hearing-impaired actors by Jeff Calhoun, who directed and choreographed the production here for the Deaf West Theater Company and the Center Theater Group. (Mr. Calhoun performed the same chores on the ebullient Deaf West production of ''Big River,'' which was warmly received when it moved to Broadway in 2003.)

headline.main: A Prince Faces Inner Demons Through Song and Sign

snippet: Deaf West Theater Company and the Center Theater Group in Los Angeles have collaborated on an aggressively saucy new revival of “Pippin.”

lead_paragraph: She's not the first Anne Hathaway linked to Shakespeare -- when you last saw this one in Central Park she was most likely racing to complete an errand for the tyrannical Miranda Priestly in "The Devil Wears Prada." But this summer, you'll be able to see Ms. Hathaway in the Shakespeare in the Park production of "Twelfth Night," in which she will play Viola, the Public Theater said in a news release. The play, directed by Daniel Sullivan, will run from June 9 through July 12 at the Delacorte Theater. The season's second production will be Euripides' "The Bacchae," directed by JoAnne Akalaitis and featuring music by Philip Glass.

headline.main: Anne Hathaway to Star in Shakespeare in the Park's 'Twelfth Night'

abstract: The other Anne Hathaway -- not the one who was married to the playwright -- will star in Shakespeare in the Park's production of "Twelfth Night."

lead_paragraph: FOR 10 years, Anthony Barboza haunted jazz clubs in Manhattan, often staying till the wee hours as he took black and white photos of musicians swirling with movement. For five years before that, he invited prominent figures in African-American culture to his studio, where he photographed them against backdrops that he devised as he got to know his subjects. These were the projects that fed his soul, Mr. Barboza said last week at the African American Museum of Nassau County in Hempstead, where an exhibition of his photographs is on display through March 10.

lead_paragraph: Now that Michael Jackson is holding a fire sale of his personal memorabilia, that makes two high-profile collections coming under the hammer this season. On Feb. 23 to 25, the auction of Yves St. Laurent's Mondrians and Limoges, collected with Pierre Bergé, is set to become the highest grossing private sale in history. Come April, Jacko will be offering up some really cool rhinestone tube socks. Here, a vernissage of comparable items from both auctions (St. Laurent on the left; Jackson on the right).

headline.main: At Auction | Clash of the Titans

abstract: Now that Michael Jackson is holding a fire sale of his personal memorabilia, that makes two high-profile collections coming under the hammer this season. On Feb. 23 to 25, the auction of Yves St. Laurent's Mondrians and Limoges, collected with Pierre Berger, is set to become the highest grossing private sale in history. Come April, Jacko will be offering up some really cool rhinestone tube socks. Here, a vernissage of comparable items from both auctions (St. Laurent on the left; Jackson on the right).Both collections prize the male form. For YSL, the more chiseled the better. For Jackson, it's all about capes and anatomically correct parts.The King of Pop and the King of Fashion had similar taste in heroic statues. But with all those white gloves, epaulets and tassels, Jackson clearly took his Napoleon complex to the next level.YSL was always a patron of good design, like this Jean-Michel Frank rock-crystal lamp from the 1920s. The Man in the Mirror likes shiny things.
snippet: Now that Michael Jackson is holding a fire sale of his personal memorabilia, that makes two high-profile collections coming under the hammer this season. On Feb. 23 to 25, the auction of Yves St. Laurent's Mondrians and Limoges, collected with Pierre...

lead_paragraph: It's not clear if art fairs are dying or going back to their ''used to be,'' in the words sung by Bessie Smith. Either way, this year's Art Show, courtesy of the Art Dealers Association of America, is pretty much ''same as it ever was,'' to borrow from David Byrne. Razzle-dazzle spectacle, stampeding collectors and buy-it-now pressure-cooking has never been the Art Show's style; neither has aisle upon aisle of booths stretching as far as the eye can see. But the times may be catching up with it.

headline.main: Rewards and Clarity In a Show of Restraint

snippet: Razzle-dazzle spectacle, stampeding collectors and buy-it-now pressure-cooking has never been the Art Show’s style. But the times may be catching up with it.

lead_paragraph: The San Francisco 49ers and the Minnesota Vikings may be interested in acquiring the suspended Atlanta Falcons star Michael Vick, who is in federal prison on felony charges related to dogfighting and is scheduled to be released in July. The Falcons have said they will try to trade him, although they could cut him and make him a free agent. San Francisco Coach Mike Singletary said Vick deserved the chance to play in the league, and said he believed that Vick would be successful if he returned. He would not say if the 49ers would pursue him.

lead_paragraph: THE Frozen Cup stand of Bellerose, Queens, which sits on Jericho Turnpike just east of the Cross Island Parkway, is painted the cheerful red and white of a candy cane. For nearly 70 years, the Frozen Cup served ice cream both soft and hard, and milkshakes, too. Parents in this working- and middle-class neighborhood of tidy Cape and Tudor homes bordering Nassau County drove their children to the Frozen Cup after Little League games. In summer, families strolled the neighborhood's streets, stopping at the ice cream stand for vanilla cones with extra chocolate sprinkles. Children sat with their cones on the curb, melted ice cream dripping onto little knees.

headline.main: The Great Divide

snippet: The beloved Frozen Cup ice cream stand of Bellerose is poised to make way for a Days Inn, a prospect that reveals the ethnic tensions just beneath the surface of a tranquil Queens neighborhood.

multimedia.caption: Neighborhood Mix
multimedia.credit: Ethnic tensions stir as South Asian immigrants succeed in largely white, Bellerose, Queens.

lead_paragraph: From the moment she arrived in Paris in 1925, toward the end of the seminal Art Deco exhibition that led to a collective embrace of all things African, Josephine Baker was a muse among muses, inspiring the likes of Picasso, Alexander Calder, Gertrude Stein, Colette and Adolf Loos. The embodiment of the Harlem Renaissance and the Jazz Age, she was modernism made flesh -- the athletic, long-limbed analogue of Stravinsky's ''Rite of Spring.'' No surprise, then, that this proto-overachiever -- at one time or another, Baker, the musical revue star, was also a screen actress, pilot, novelist, entrepreneur, civil rights activist and counterespionage agent -- was also catnip for the era's leading designers, most notably Paul Poiret, who showered her with furs, gowns and hundreds of shoes before unsuccessfully suing her to have them returned when he was facing bankruptcy.

headline.main: Temptress Josephine

lead_paragraph: Andy Warhol's grandchildren, numerous beyond count, have cashed in on his legacy in varied ways. Some have done replays of the classic art-as-fandom routine associated with Warhol's Elvis and Marilyn portraits. Shephard Fairey of Barack Obama poster fame is in this category. Others have dug into this heritage, a rich and radical one, to see what fresh possibilities it might yield. Such is the case with the New York artist Jonathan Horowitz, who has a smart, crisply edited retrospective at the P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center.

headline.main: When a Can of Worms Is Opened, an Artist Does Some Fishing

snippet: Jonathan Horowitz's retrospective at the P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center is a survey that looks as though it were made of many random parts, but feels of a piece.

lead_paragraph: ARMITSTEAD--Reverend Austin Herrick, 84, passed away peacefully February 20, 2009 in his home. Reverend Armitstead was born on December 30, 1924 in Nashua, New Hampshire and spent his childhood and teenage years in New England and Pennsylvania before enlisting in the Army in early 1943. Armitstead fought for freedom as an infantryman in the 12th Armored Division seeing action along the Rhine River near Strausburg, France until taken as a prisoner of war in early 1945. After his liberation in April 1945 he returned to the United States and civilian life. He graduated Dickinson College in Carlisle, PA in 1948 and having decided to dedicate his life to the service of God, worked with migrant farm workers from northern Florida through northern New York before enrolling in Union Theological Seminary in New York City where he was awarded a Masters of Divinity in 1952. He married his wife, Bianca Audrey Potz-Nielsen in 1951 and the couple began a lifetime of ministry together. Reverend Armitstead was an elder in the New York Conference of the United Methodist Church and served pastorates in Hauppauge, Commack and Center Moriches on Long Island, Bay Ridge Methodist Church in Brooklyn, Faith United Methodist Church on Staten Island and Community United Methodist Church in Jackson Heights, Queens where he established a four language church bringing a diverse community together in service to God. Upon his retirement in 1994, he served as a Community Liaison for the Western Queens Gazette and offered his personal ministry through his photographic works. In addition to his pastoral responsibilities Armitstead was also a leader and advocate for social change and justice in each of his stops along life's path. He was an early and vocal advocate for racial integration and equality and also worked tirelessly in the cause of ecumenicalism and community responsibility upon the part of the churches he served. He held positions as President, Vice-President or Chairman on a number of boards in New York including the Salvation Army, American Red Cross, Police Community Relations, Staten Island Council of Churches, Brooklyn United Methodist Church Home, Jackson Heights Community Development, sheltered New York City homeless, served the New York City Police and Fire Departments in a number of ways, and served on numerous task forces of New York City Mayors, improving the lives of thousands. His passion for championing the underdog was also evident in his life-long love of baseball as he was an avid New York Mets fan and attended nearly a thousand ball games at Shea Stadium in Queens. Perhaps fitting, Armitstead died only a few days after the last remaining piece of that ballpark was leveled. He was an honorary lifetime member of the Baseball Hall of Fame. Due to declining health, Armitstead and his wife moved to Suffolk in the summer of 2007 where he lived out his life close to family. Reverend Armitstead is survived by his wife of over 57 years, Bianca Audrey Potz-Nielsen Armitstead; one daughter, Nancy Armitstead of New York City; two sons, Alan Jackson Armitstead (wife, Petra) of Suffolk and John Auman Armitstead (wife, Ima) of Lexington, Kentucky; two brothers, Donald M. Armitstead of Seattle, WA and Dr. Paul T. Armitstead of Waco, TX; and five grandchildren, Christian, Jaclyn, Michael, Steven and Jonathan. A memorial service will be held on Friday, February 27, at 11am in Sturtevant Funeral Home, Bennetts Creek Chapel, Suffolk celebrated by the Reverend Bob Weeks of Aldersgate United Methodist Church. Ground committal will be in the Albert G. Horton, Jr. Memorial Veterans Cemetery also in Suffolk. Contributions in lieu of flowers should be made to your local church, hospice, food bank, the Salvation Army or Red Cross. www.SturtevantFuneralHome. com

lead_paragraph: Anyone who has played even some basketball would appreciate Shane Battier's contributions to the success of every team he has ever played with (Feb. 15). Back in the day, the N.B.A. could point to Jim McMillan of the Lakers (not coincidentally the catalyst for the team that still holds the league's longest winning streak) and Bill Bradley (arguably the ''glue'' for two Knicks championship teams) as similar players with less-than-gaudy statistics whose sense of where they were on the court made their teams better. We didn't have Daryl Morey's math skills to prove it, so it's good to see that there are now real tools to measure what our common sense told us then was true. JOEL M. RUDELL New York

lead_paragraph: IT was Valentine's Day 2007, and the Rev. J. Lee Hill Jr. was battling a snowstorm that slowed his progress to Lower Manhattan for a community forum on troubled children. The Baptist minister skulked in 45 minutes late and was ready to bury his head in embarrassment when Christie Nicole Love, a tall, brown-eyed woman across the table, caught his eye.

headline.main: Christie Love and J. Lee Hill Jr.

snippet: The couple felt an immediate kinship during their first encounter, and they solidified that initial connection the day after this Valentine’s Day in Riverside’s soaring Gothic cathedral.

Another person featured in the campaign, Fernando Kabigting, 69, an artist who had a debilitating stroke and then taught himself to paint with his left hand, received $300 from a fellow artist who had also suffered a stroke.

lead_paragraph: On the boy island that is ''South Park,'' Comedy Central's long-running series, adult supervision is more often tolerated than heeded. For the most part, Stan, Kyle, Cartman and Kenny seem to listen carefully and then do what they want. That general imperative hangs near at South Park Studios in Los Angeles. With a vast 25,000-square-foot operation that can produce a new episode in a week, Matt Stone and Trey Parker, the creators and principals of ''South Park,'' do work they like, control its digital sale and display, and participate in its profits.

headline.main: 'South Park,' A Vision And a Payoff

abstract: David Carr interview with Matt Stone and Trey Parker, creators and principals of South Park, Comedy Central's highest-rated show; they comment on deal they and network have entered into with Netflix to stream first nine seasons of South Park (M)
snippet: While Hollywood and network studios are struggling to find the future, the creators of the show “South Park” have created a visionary broadcasting model.

lead_paragraph: As Roland W. Burris, the junior senator from Illinois, took his first turn presiding over the Senate last week, hired staff members to fill his Washington office and announced co-sponsorship of a measure commemorating the role of slaves in building the Capitol, politicians back home were plotting who might replace him. Gov. Patrick J. Quinn said he would give Mr. Burris, a fellow Democrat, two weeks to quit before urging Illinois lawmakers to consider a special election that could, in essence, remove the senator from the seat he was appointed to after Barack Obama was elected president. And as the prestigious Union League Club of Chicago joined a chorus last week calling on Mr. Burris to resign, the state's attorney general, Lisa Madigan, also a Democrat, issued an opinion that such an election could pass legal muster.

headline.main: A Line Forms to Succeed Burris, Sooner or Later

snippet: No one knows when the Senate election will occur  in 2010, as planned, or in the coming weeks or months in a special election, seen as unlikely but conceivable.

lead_paragraph: The movie is based on a famous comic series by the Belgian writer and artist George Prosper Remi, who worked under the pen name Herge. French speakers, and those who honor their language, variously pronounce the character's name as, approximately, "tahn-tahn" or "tan-tan," depending on the individual's accent, but always with something nasal happening toward the "n"'s. Both can be heard in the French-language discussion posted here, from a comics festival in Angouleme, France, earlier this year.

headline.main: It's Tin Men vs. Tan Men in Spielberg's Adventure Film

abstract: Steven Spielberg's upcoming "Adventures of Tintin" poses an unusual problem: How do you pronounce the hero's name? Is it "tan-tan," as the French would have it, or "tin-tin," as Spielberg and others have said it?

lead_paragraph: Proving that this decade really is the 1980s in quotation marks, Michael Jackson announced that he would perform a series of concerts in London this summer, in what the singer called a "final curtain call," Reuters reported. Mr. Jackson, 50, revealed the details of the concerts at a news conference Thursday in London, where he said he would perform 10 shows at that city's O2 Arena, beginning July 8. "When I say this is it, I mean this is it," Mr. Jackson said, according to Reuters. "I'll be performing the songs my fans want to hear." The shows would be Mr. Jackson's first major performances since 2001 and 2002, when he appeared at a pair of 30th anniversary celebrations and two benefit concerts; a brief appearance by Mr. Jackson at the World Music Awards in 2006 was booed by audience members.

headline.main: Michael Jackson to Play 'Final' Concerts in London

lead_paragraph: How powerful is Rush Limbaugh? Well, powerful enough to make Michael Steele, chairman of the Republican National Committee, apologize for calling the radio host a mere "entertainer." Possibly powerful enough to cost Steele his job. But powerful enough to force President Obama to debate him? You'd think that would be highly unlikely, but as we found out this week, the White House is going to do everything in its power to keep Limbaugh at the forefront of public consciousness.

lead_paragraph: ''Feds Interview Obama on 'Pay-to-Play' '' was the Washington Times headline last Christmas Eve, subheaded ''Team's Blagojevich review finds 'nothing inappropriate' '' in contacts between Gov. Rod Blagojevich of Illinois and White House aides about the replacement for the Senate seat Barack Obama was vacating. That was about the suspected ''sale'' of the appointment by the F.B.I.-wiretapped governor, who was ultimately impeached and removed. Three weeks later, above an editorial headlined ''The Price of Pay-to-Play'' and a reminder that ''the most brazen episode of pay-to-play of late'' was in the Blagojevich affair, The New York Times used the same compound phrase about the withdrawal of Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico from nomination to the Obama cabinet. The editorial held that the New Mexico governor ''backed away from the chance to run the Commerce Department as federal prosecutors investigate whether his aides steered a lucrative state contract to a generous political donor.''

headline.main: Pay-to-Play

snippet: A phrase for all seasons.

lead_paragraph: None of the guests seemed to be complaining, yet Michael Steele stood at a Fifth Avenue fund-raiser in New York on Wednesday evening and defended his month-old tenure as chairman of the Republican National Committee. Yes, some of his problems in the job were ''self-inflicted,'' he said, ''but I do things to get a reaction.''

lead_paragraph: CHRIS CORNELL ''Scream'' (Mosley Music/Interscope) Rockers feeling stale can always jump genres. Darius Rucker of Hootie and the Blowfish went country last year; now the rocker Chris Cornell introduces electrogrunge on ''Scream,'' his third solo album. Mr. Cornell, a grunge pioneer with Soundgarden in the 1980s and 1990s, wrote all the songs on ''Scream,'' but most of the music sets aside big guitar chords to embrace the synthetic pulse and programmed hooks produced by the hip-hop and R&B hit maker Tim Mosley, a k a Timbaland.

lead_paragraph: Hyperbaric oxygen therapy was long called a treatment in search of diseases. But in recent years, laboratory and clinical studies have found more than a dozen serious diseases for which it is considered a valuable -- and sometimes life-saving -- treatment. Although the administration of pure oxygen in a high-pressure chamber has been around as a therapy for more than 300 years, it is only now beginning to reach its potential, according to a report in the November issue of the journal Emergency Medicine.

lead_paragraph: When the lights go down at the end of the first movement of Paul Taylor's ''Esplanade'' (1975) or ''Mercuric Tidings'' (1982) in the Taylor company's current City Center season, the audience bursts into the kind of applause you usually hear only as a dance ends. Quite right, too: those movements are ebullient, complete experiences, rich in variety. But then in both pieces the lights go up a moment later on a slow movement that shows some kind of poignancy. At once we know the world onstage has changed, deepened, grown darker and larger. Now we realize that we have far to go before we reach completion. In these two works and in so many others, Mr. Taylor's is the art of drastic contrasts: of sun and shade, of heroes and insects, of rush and reflectiveness.

headline.main: Carefree Contrast in the Dreamscapes of a Poet
headline.kicker: DANCE REVIEW | PAUL TAYLOR DANCE COMPANY

snippet: In “Esplanade,” “Mercuric Tidings” and in so many others, Paul Taylor’s is the art of drastic contrasts: of sun and shade, of heroes and insects, of rush and reflectiveness.

lead_paragraph: What began as a humble farewell from Michael Jackson to 200,000 or so of his fondest fans has somehow metamorphosed into a spectacle. The concert promoter AEG Live announced that it would add 13 dates to Mr. Jackson's "This Is It" concert series, which begins on July 8 at London's O2 Arena. The king of pop's first 10 shows sold out quickly on Wednesday morning, The Associated Press reported, and his new dates, also at the O2 Arena, will take him through Sept. 10, with more concerts expected to be announced. In a news conference on March 5 to announce the first 10 shows, Mr. Jackson described them as a "final curtain call," adding, "When I say this is it, I mean this is it."

lead_paragraph: It has been 40 years since Jean-Charles de Castelbajac first formed his fashion vocabulary -- a nursery tale seen through the lens of Andy Warhol and spelled out in bold, bright colors. But this wide-eyed, childlike view of the fashion world has grown into a brand that keeps on resonating in pop culture. ''The show has many of my historic ideas -- teddy bears, the mix of man and women -- and the Andy wigs that he never put on straight,'' said Castelbajac backstage, pointing out his cult shoes, in collaboration with Free Lance, that had animal faces staring out at the toes.

lead_paragraph: It took only five hours for tickets to sell out for all 50 concerts of Michael Jackson's comeback series in London, which is set to begin July 8, Reuters reported this morning.Mr. Jackson, whose last set of concerts was the "HIStory World Tour" 12 years ago, initially committed to 10 shows at London's O2 Arena, but he added another 40 that will extend the run to Feb. 24, 2010. "This is it, the final curtain call," Mr. Jackson said at a news conference this month announcing the shows. "I just wanted to say that these will be my final show performances in London. When I say this is it, it really means this is it."Mr. Jackson's last album of new music was "Invincible" in 2001. He all but withdrew from public life after his acquittal on child abuse charges in 2005 and has been struggling with debts that contributed to his loss of his Neverland ranch and miniature amusement park in California.

Now, half a century after each was founded, the labels live on in their hometowns, one an industrial city up north, another a river city in the South.

lead_paragraph: Someone had to do it. On Tuesday evening at the Metropolitan Room, Anne Steele, a singer who would probably be at home competing on ''American Idol,'' sang a Britney Spears hit (''Toxic'') in close proximity to a Stephen Sondheim ballad (''Move On''). That is what is called a stretch. But Ms. Steele, who won the Metropolitan Room's MetroStar Talent Challenge last summer, more or less pulled it off. The juxtaposition even makes sense considering the childlike vocal qualities of Ms. Spears and Bernadette Peters, who introduced ''Move On'' in ''Sunday in the Park With George.'' Ms. Steele, it should be noted, is not one to explore the subtexts of lyrics. She breezed confidently through the Sondheim song while keeping it at arm's length emotionally. The song to which she gave the closest reading was Cat Stevens's fraught generational dialogue, ''Father and Son.''

headline.main: Rubbing Elbows in Song, Britney Spears and Sondheim

snippet: The Spears-Sondheim pairing made sense given the concept of Anne Steele’s show “Strings Attached,” which began an encore engagement at the club on Tuesday.

lead_paragraph: The volume of toxic chemicals that were released into the environment or sent for disposal in 2007 dropped 5 percent compared with 2006, the Environmental Protection Agency said Thursday. But concealed within the overall numbers was good and bad news. For example, the volume of released or disposed ''persistent, bioaccumulative and toxic chemicals,'' substances like lead, dioxin, mercury and PCBs, was up slightly, the agency said. Most of those releases were not to air or water, the agency said, meaning that the material was mostly buried in landfills, injected into deep wells or held in impoundments.

headline.main: A Drop in Toxic Emissions And a Rise in PCB Disposal

snippet: The volume of toxic chemicals that were released into the environment or sent for disposal dropped 5 percent, but some bad news accompanied the good numbers.

lead_paragraph: FROM LAP DOGS TO SNOW GLOBES to Fabergé eggs, miniatures have always delighted humanity, and -- if my vacations are any indication -- countries are no exception. In my travels, I've often gone hundreds of miles out of my way to visit improbably tiny sovereign states, not knowing myself what it was that drew me to them, and usually regretting the detour. Andorra, that enigmatic republic in the Pyrenees, revealed itself to be a cluster of duty-free shops and dusty, neglected-looking hills; Monaco felt like a glorified suburb of Nice; and Vatican City, despite the pomp, seemed like little more than one of Rome's less charming neighborhoods. As with any obsession, however, disappointment only sharpened my desire. The impossible country of my imagination existed somewhere, I was sure of it: the fact that I hadn't been there yet was the best proof of its magical obscurity. What's more, I had a hunch as to this mysterious nation's location, and even as to what it might be called. I was reasonably sure its name was Liechtenstein. The principality of Liechtenstein, sandwiched between Switzerland and Austria, is one of only two doubly landlocked countries in the world, meaning that all of its direct neighbors are landlocked as well. (The other is Uzbekistan.) It is the sixth-smallest nation in area, the seventh-smallest in population and the smallest in which German is spoken. Its citizens, just over 35,000 at last count, speak a wide variety of Alpine dialects, a number of which could be unintelligible to a visitor from Vienna or Hamburg or Munich. Simply getting to the principality is something of an adventure, both straightforward and strangely involved, as though someone -- the Swiss? the princely family? the I.R.S.? -- were trying to discourage the casual visitor. Liechtenstein has no airport, and the eminently comfortable and efficient train from Zurich stops on either side of the principality but not actually inside it. The last five miles require a bus, a taxi, a bicycle or possibly a donkey, of which there are surprisingly many in Liechtenstein. I opted for the bus, partly because it was simplest and partly to test the reliability of the country's renowned public transportation system. I was not disappointed.

headline.main: The Royal Wee

abstract: Travel article on tiny Alpine principality of Liechtenstein; photos (Special section, Travel Spring 2009) (L)
snippet: A turn through the tiny principality of Liechtenstein.

lead_paragraph: A wrongful termination lawsuit filed by a former professor against the University of Colorado has been unfolding in exciting fashion in a courtroom here. The professor, Ward L. lead_paragraph: Music competitions are often criticized for being unfair or biased and for an unseemly reliance on scorecards. But for better or worse they are still a standard way for young musicians to gain recognition and financial support. One of the most prestigious contests for promising young singers (35 and under) in North America is the George London Foundation Awards Competition, named for a renowned American bass-baritone. Past winners include Joyce DiDonato, Renée Fleming and Matthew Polenzani. At the final round of the 38th annual event on Friday afternoon in Gilder Lehrman Hall at the Morgan Library & Museum, 26 young singers performed before a panel of judges that included the soprano Harolyn Blackwell, the mezzo-soprano Rosalind Elias and Nora London, George London's widow and the president of the foundation. Earlier in the week the judges heard 100 singers, selected from almost 300 applicants.

headline.main: Big Ambition, Small Hall At Singers' Competition

snippet: At the final round of the 38th annual George London Foundation Awards Competition on Friday in Gilder Lehrman Hall at the Morgan Library & Museum, 26 young singers performed before a panel of judges.

lead_paragraph: A small group of Democratic state senators from Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx have blocked a financial rescue proposal for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority because it would require tolls on the East River and Harlem River bridges. They have taken this position even though the plan is meant to help hold down transit fares, and in their districts -- as in the city overall -- commuters who ride subways and buses easily outnumber those who drive to work.

headline.main: Unlikely Opponents of Bridge Tolls: Transit Riders

snippet: Even some commuters who rely on public transit objected to tolls on bridges over the East and Harlem Rivers.

lead_paragraph: The Vanderbilt Knockout Teams, the premier event at the Spring North American Championships in Houston, was won in the early hours of Sunday morning by Ralph Katz, George Jacobs, Bobby Levin, Steve Weinstein and two Egyptian players, Walid el-Ahmady and Tarek Sadek. Trailing by one international match point after 32 of the 64 boards, the Katz team won the second half by 62 imps to 23 over John Diamond, Brian Platnick, Fred Gitelman, Brad Moss, Eric Greco and Geoff Hampson. In Friday's semifinals Diamond had easily defeated the top seeds, Nick Nickell, Richard Freeman, Bob Hamman, Zia Mahmood, Jeff Meckstroth and Eric Rodwell, by 171 imps to 133, despite losing 50 imps in the fourth quarter. Katz had beaten the second seeds, James Cayne, Michael Seamon and four Italians -- Fulvio Fantoni, Claudio Nunes, Lorenzo Lauria and Alfredo Versace -- by 129 imps to 108.

headline.main: Vanderbilt Title Captured By Katz Team

snippet: The Vanderbilt Knockout Teams, the premier event at the Spring North American Championships in Houston, was won in the early hours of Sunday morning.

lead_paragraph: Karen O, the banshee-like frontwoman for Yeah Yeah Yeahs, is one of the ought's most captivating performers and something of a Gen Y style icon. But she is more than that: she is an artist in her own right who scored the music to Spike Jonze's new film, "Where the Wild Things Are," studied film at the Tisch School of the Arts and recently exhibited a piece of sculpture at the Fuse Gallery in downtown Manhattan. The Moment caught up with the outrageous Ms. O to discuss her band's excellent -- and vastly different-sounding -- new album, "It's Blitz," and also to discover her personal aesthetic and why she was voted "Most Atypical" in high school.

headline.main: Now Playing | Yeah Yeah Yeahs

abstract: Karen O, the banshee-like frontwoman for Yeah Yeah Yeahs, is one of the ought's most captivating performers and something of a Gen Y style icon. But she is more than that: she is an artist in her own right who scored the music to Spike Jonze's new film, "Where the Wild Things Are," studied film at the Tisch School of the Arts and recently exhibited a piece of sculpture at the Fuse Gallery in downtown Manhattan. The Moment caught up with the outrageous Ms. O to discuss her band's excellent -- and vastly different-sounding -- new album, "It's Blitz," and also to discover her personal aesthetic and why she was voted "Most Atypical" in high school.Yeah Yeah Yeahs' new album, "It's Blitz," has more of a 1980s sound than past albums, with synthesizers and traces of artists like Til Tuesday, Gary Numan and the Cocteau Twins. Was there a conscious decision to change the band's sound?It all happened pretty organically and spontaneously. There wasn't much intention to go in that direction, but after we wrote the first two songs, "Zero" [the new single] and "Skeleton," which both incorporate that pulsating synth sound, it set the scene for the record.You recorded "It's Blitz" in a fairly remote part of West Texas. How did working there impact your creative process?Texas was amazing. On one hand, it was like a creative retreat, going to the studio every day in a place where we felt completely detached. But it was surreal having that amount of space in the desert and being surrounded by all these pecan trees -- there are miles and miles of pecan trees there. But it allowed us to dig in our heels and get back to our roots as a band.For the album artwork, which has a photograph on an egg being smashed by a hand, you enlisted Urs Fischer, the artist who made that huge crater at Gavin Brown Enterprises a few years back. How did you come to work with him?My friend Trztn was Urs's assistant and Urs did the cover for his band, Services, which I loved. It has a woman's eyelash with a wad of spit on it, which takes a second to figure out. It's pretty bold. I thought he would be great with a cover that reflected a sound like nothing we had ever recorded before.In interviews you've name-checked the Dadaist and Surrealist movements as influences. Are they a big part of your aesthetic sensibility?I like humor, and Dada and surreality are part of my expression, as is emotional honesty, not taking some things so seriously, and revealing the absurdity of things. It leaves a lot of room for interpretation,but that sensibility matches a big part of me.On stage you can seem maniacal. It's kind of like Iggy Pop's approach to live performance. Where does your wild abandon come from?I got turned onto Iggy late in the game. If anything, it was where I grew up in New Jersey, in Engelwood and Cresskill. I had a ton of angst. I was an outsider. In my high school, you know the senior poll with people getting "Best Legs" or "Best Smile"? I got "Most Atypical."Since the beginning of YYY's, you've collaborated with the designer Christian Joy, whose costumes are wild and campy. Yet they seem to complement your stage persona.Her designs complete me as a performer, a musician and a rocker -- I guess that's the best way to describe it. To a certain extent the costumes she makes me are a challenge that I have to live up to and work out. Do you design the clothes with her?We'll talk about general broad concepts, but in the end she'll do what she wants to do.What's your wardrobe like? Do you have lots of designer clothes?Thinking about my closets reminds me of the spring cleaning I desperately need to do. I love vintage and mixing it with my can't-live-without day-to-day pieces. More than anything I'm a vintage girl. In the new video for "Zero," you're wearing a "Karen O" leather jacket. What was the fashion impetus behind that?

lead_paragraph: Rabbi Capers Funnye celebrated Martin Luther King Day this year in New York City at the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue, a mainstream Reform congregation, in the company of about 700 fellow Jews -- many of them black. The organizers of the event had reached out to four of New York's Black Jewish synagogues in the hope of promoting Jewish diversity, and they weren't disappointed. African-American Jews, largely from Brooklyn, the Bronx and Queens, many of whom had never been in a predominantly white synagogue, made up about a quarter of the audience. Most of the visiting women wore traditional African garb; the men stood out because, though it was a secular occasion, most kept their heads covered. But even with your eyes closed you could tell who was who: the black Jews and the white Jews clapped to the music on different beats. Funnye, the chief rabbi of the Beth Shalom B'nai Zaken Ethiopian Hebrew Congregation in Chicago, one of the largest black synagogues in America, was a featured speaker that night. The overflowing audience came out in a snowstorm to hear his thoughts about two men: the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Barack Obama. King is Funnye's hero. Obama, whose inauguration was to take place the following day in Washington, is family -- the man who married Funnye's cousin Michelle.

headline.main: Obama's Rabbi

snippet: Like his cousins Michelle and Barack Obama, Capers Funnye, the head of one of the largest black synagogues in the United States, wants to reach across the aisle  in his case, to white Jews.

lead_paragraph: THE auction later this month of Michael Jackson's personal belongings has piqued the interest of fashion followers. Among the 2,000 lots from Neverland Ranch are the kind of broad-shouldered jackets and crystal-adorned accessories that have, in no indirect way, served as inspiration for the insanely coveted Balmain collections. And many are likely to be much lower in price than Balmain's. A rhinestone belt worn by Mr. Jackson on his 1979 Destiny tour has an estimated value of $400 to $600; a black wool military jacket (right) worn to visit a Romanian orphanage -- the photo to prove it, included -- is set at $800 to $1,200; and Mr. Jackson's crystal-studded gloves (not seen at Balmain, but fabulous no less) have an estimate of $1,500 each.

lead_paragraph: In the right context conventional virtues have a way of gleaming like fresh seams of gold. The most satisfying production at the 33rd Humana Festival of New American Plays at the Actors Theater here, a two-act contemporary drama called ''Absalom'' by Zoe Kazan, was also the most traditional. Many playwrights represented at the festival were busy wagging fingers and wringing hands about the sorry state of American culture and society in works either unfocused, confused, coy or cloying. In contrast Ms. Kazan dusted off the solid building blocks of 20th-century American drama to construct a new play about that enduring staple, the fraying family. With its believably human characters, intriguing tangle of relationships, playable dialogue and cozy setting in the Berkshires, this promising new play all but dazzled by achieving its relatively modest aims.

headline.main: Another Bow for the Fraying Family

snippet: The most satisfying production at the 33rd Humana Festival of New American Plays, a two-act drama by Zoe Kazan called “Absalom,” was also the most traditional.

lead_paragraph: Hours after an extensive collection of memorabilia owned by Michael Jackson went on view for a public auction, the auctioneer and Mr. Jackson announced Tuesday that they had agreed to cancel the sale and return the property to him. Mr. Jackson hired Julien's Auctions last year to sell the contents of Neverland Valley Ranch, his former estate northwest of Los Angeles, and the company put together an auction of more than 1,000 items. But last month Mr. Jackson's company, MJJ Productions, sued to prevent the auction, saying that he had not been given an opportunity to review the items in advance.

lead_paragraph: Great works of art often tote heavy baggage. Yet the revival of August Wilson's ''Joe Turner's Come and Gone,'' a drama of indisputable greatness, feels positively airborne. Much of Bartlett Sher's splendid production, which opened Thursday night at the Belasco Theater, moves with the engaging ease of lively, casual conversation. Some part of you, though, is always aware that there's a storm whipping within and around the breezy talk, a gale-force wind that picks up and scatters people as if they were dandelion seeds. That wind is cold, uncaring history, propelling an entire population of men and women, only 50 years out of slavery, as they try to find footholds on a land that keeps shaking them loose.

headline.main: Wilson's Wanderers, Searching For Home
headline.kicker: THEATER REVIEW | 'JOE TURNER'S COME AND GONE'

lead_paragraph: IN the weeks, months, perhaps even years to come, the interminable Minnesota Senate recount seems likely -- we're just speculating here -- to end. (One can only guess whether the newly minted senator might reprise his pelvis-gyrating 2006 party victory dance, in which he wagged an imaginary codpiece on ''The Colbert Report''; or whether he might advise voters, as he did years ago, to treat George W. She will be forever missed by her husband and soulmate Chet Tuchman, Alan and Donna Tuchman, Terri and Russell Meyers, and grandchildren Matthew, Megan, Madison and Taylor Tuchman and Sarah, Michael, Jack and Casey Meyers. lead_paragraph: KA'LIAL GLAUD, a high school senior with a big decision to make, said he was moving on with his life at full speed the moment the quarter came up tails. He would discover later that strangers would wonder why he chose a college by flipping a coin, but Glaud was certain he had exhausted every other means of making a tough decision easier. Tails meant that Glaud, a star football player at Winslow Township High School in Camden County, would attend Rutgers University to play linebacker for the Scarlet Knights. Had the coin landed heads-up, it would have been West Virginia University.

lead_paragraph: In a nearly empty high school auditorium one evening last month, parents, teachers and cynics marched to the microphone, turned to the collection of volunteers derisively called the Panel for Educational Puppets, and began to scream. A vocational school teacher in East New York, Brooklyn, accused bureaucrats of manipulating college enrollment data. Parents protested a plan to move their school to East Harlem from Midtown. And Olaiya Deen, the mother of a third grader, deplored the proliferation of charter schools and ''Madison Avenue'' marketing blitzes to promote them in her neighborhood.

headline.main: In Debate Over Schools, Panel Is No Threat to the Mayor's Grip

abstract: Second article in Controlling Interests series, which is examining Bloomberg administration's record on education as state lawmakers debate renewal of law giving control of New York City's public schools to mayor; focuses on Panel for Education Policy, oversight group that replaced independent Board of Education in 2002; recalls that state lawmakers viewed panel as critical to maintaining balance of authority and promised it would have meaningful role on citywide education policy and approve major contracts; says Mayor Michael R Bloomberg, who controls 8 of panel's 13 seats, and Schools Chancellor Joel I Klein, who doubles as panel's chairman, have eased it into irrevelance; says volunteers who make up panel rarely engage in discussions with those who rise to address them at monthly meetings and do not debate educational issues of day, but rather spend most sessions applauding packaged presentations by staff; photos; profiles of 12 current panel members (L)
snippet: In the debate over extending mayoral control of New York City schools, an oversight group’s role is under scrutiny.

lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM | Thursday is Queensday, a national holiday to commemorate the birthday of the Queen of the Netherlands, and the biggest party in the country (although the celebration actually starts Wednesday night). If you happen to be in Amsterdam, you're in for big crowds and plenty of people watching. The streets of the city will overflow with drinks, good spirits and streams of orange-clad revelers as the locals engage in their yearly sort of spring cleaning: many clear out their closets for a sort of mass garage sale, and already all over the city, small parcels of sidewalk are marked off with tape and labeled "bezet," or "reserved."

lead_paragraph: Around the nation, drugstores have sold out of surgical masks. Schools have closed, sports games have been called off, and doctors' offices -- and their phone lines -- are jammed. The truly anxious confess that they are trying to avoid touching elevator buttons, library books and the knobs on bathroom sinks. As the number of confirmed swine flu cases in this country continued to rise to over 100 on Thursday, precautions over the illness -- many of which appeared to be overreactions -- were beginning to affect the daily lives of tens of thousands of people, even in states where the flu has yet to be found.

headline.main: Overdose of Caution? Thousands Face Balancing Act on Flu Fears

abstract: Confirmed cases of swine flu in United States rise to over 100, and people say they are struggling with balancing act between taking precautions and overreacting; drugstores around nation have sold out of surgical masks, schools have closed, sports games have been canceled and doctors' offices are jammed; precautions over illness are affecting daily lives of tens of thousands of people, even in areas where flu has yet to be found; many people confess that they are trying to avoid elevator buttons, library books and knobs on bathroom sinks; doctors in some places say they are overwhelmed with patients, some of whom insistently seek tests for swine flu though they show no symptoms; other people around country, however, seem perplexed at thought that anyone would change their behavior given relatively small number of confirmed cases; photo (M)
snippet: Precautions are affecting daily life around the country, even in states where swine flu has yet to be found.

lead_paragraph: Re ''Telling the Brutal Truth'' (April 26): When I went through the Navy's Survival, Evasion, Resistance and Escape training program in 1966, before shipping out to Vietnam where I flew many combat missions, everyone -- those who ran the program and those who underwent the training -- referred to what was done to us as ''torture.'' We operated on the assumption that that was the whole point of it, to prepare us for full-scale torture by subjecting us to a smaller-scale version of it. There would have been no point to it if we hadn't understood the direct connection between what was done to us at the SERE camp and what we could expect if we were shot down and captured.

headline.main: Other Voices: What Do You Call Torture? Torture

lead_paragraph: A publicist and manager for Michael Jackson has sued the pop singer for $44 million, saying that she had not been paid for several deals she negotiated for him, The Associated Press reported. In a lawsuit filed Tuesday in United States District Court in Washington, Raymone Bain, a lawyer who has also represented clients including Muhammad Ali, Kenneth "Babyface" Edmonds and Serena Williams, said that Mr. Jackson had agreed to pay her 10 percent of any agreements that she handled for him. She said that the deals she struck for him include the release of a 25th anniversary edition CD of his album "Thriller" album, the refinancing of a loan Mr. Jackson used to retain his rights to the Beatles' song catalog, and negotiations that led to his coming concert series in London. In a statement, Ms. Bain said: "I have no regrets. Michael Jackson, in my opinion, is the 'King of Pop." There was no immediate comment from Mr. Jackson or his representatives.

headline.main: Michael Jackson Is Sued by Publicist

lead_paragraph: The Virginia Democratic Party's annual Jefferson-Jackson dinner, held at Richmond's sprawl of a convention center on a mild Saturday night in February, was particularly festive this year. The Democratic Party is enjoying a resurgence in Virginia, propelled first by the November victory of Barack Obama -- the first Democratic presidential candidate to win the state since Lyndon Johnson -- and now by a lively battle for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination. There are three men who want the nomination, but on this weekend, you could be forgiven for thinking that there was only one, and that his name was Terry McAuliffe. There were McAuliffe signs everywhere, an exhausting blur of blue and yellow starting at the airport and rolling for nine miles to the entrance of the Greater Richmond Convention Center. There, bustling McAuliffe campaign workers, rolling around on electric carts, hoisted a McAuliffe for Governor banner over the street. A marching band stepped in place, before accompanying McAuliffe and his supporters as they paraded around the center, grandly announcing his arrival. Inside, volunteers scattered the hall with 2,500 McAuliffe fortune cookies, which crumbled open to reveal fortunes like high speed rail is in your future. The fortune-cookie count came courtesy of the McAuliffe campaign, which also reported that the campaign had purchased 39 dinner tables, printed 1,000 McAuliffe for Governor signs, issued 300 glow sticks to wave at the dinner and was paying for two after-dinner parties, with open bars. It was a display of political money and muscle that was quite unlike anything anyone had ever seen at the annual dinner. ''When I decide to do something,'' McAuliffe said as he marched along with his band, ''I do it.''

headline.main: GOVERNOR CLINTONISM?

snippet: Terry McAuliffe, power broker of the Clinton era, is trying to remake himself as a candidate in the age of Obama.

lead_paragraph: The umpire Paul Schrieber promptly issued an apology Thursday for placing his hand on the Detroit slugger Magglio Ordonez's back and steering him toward the dugout during a heated confrontation Wednesday night. It took even less time for Ordonez and Tigers Manager Jim Leyland to accept it. ''In yesterday's game, after I called Magglio Ordonez out on strikes, I inadvertently placed my hand on his back and ushered him away from home plate so I did not have to eject him for arguing balls and strikes,'' Schrieber said in a statement issued before the Tigers-Twins series finale on Thursday. ''I should not have placed my hands on him, period. For doing so, I apologize to both Magglio Ordonez and the Detroit Tigers.''

lead_paragraph: Populism. Now there's a word that makes you want to shout and strut and do something funky with your hips. Or that's the effect this Latinate noun has on the young and restless residents of the young and restless country portrayed with zeal in ''Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson: The Concert Version,'' the raw but tasty new musical that opened Sunday night at the Public Theater. ''Populism, Yea, Yea,'' the show's opening number, is performed by a group of sensitive and oversexed early-19th-century Americans aching for an outlet for all that pent-up adolescent energy and promising to cause major damage when they find one. They make the street thugs from ''West Side Story,'' now in revival on Broadway, look like sweet little honors students.

headline.main: Old Hickory, That Emo Punk, Singing and Dancing to Fame

snippet: This raw but tasty new musical, about the seventh president of the United States, is poised between deadpan wonder and frat-house humor.

lead_paragraph: Around this time of year, posters for the JVC Jazz Festival would be appearing on the streets of New York, and jazz tourists would be finalizing plans to arrive in the middle of June for two weeks of bragworthy shows. But for the first time in 37 years, there will be no major summer jazz festival in New York. Nor will there be related series in Miami or Chicago, as the concert company behind them is suffering a financial crisis.

lead_paragraph: Some fans of Michael Jackson who thought they would be among the first to attend his monthslong "This Is It" concert series at London's O2 Arena in July won't be seeing his performances until next year because he has rescheduled several shows, BBC News reported. The opening night of the six-month run (with a break from October through December), originally scheduled for July 8, has been postponed until July 12, while other shows planned for that month have been rescheduled for March. The BBC said the shows had been delayed so Mr. Jackson could spend more time rehearsing. In an e-mail message the promoter of the concerts, AEG Live, told the BBC, "We wanted to ensure that all of Michael's fans attending the concerts get the same quality in staging and level of entertainment."

headline.main: Michael Jackson Delays Start of 'Final' Concerts

lead_paragraph: In a turn of events that viewers have variously found surprising, validating and frustrating, the underdog contestant Kris Allen was named the winner of "American Idol" on Wednesday night, receiving more votes than Adam Lambert, who was perceived (by some) to be the likely champion. Even Mr. Allen was slightly stunned by the news: after the host Ryan Seacrest had told him he had won, he said, "Adam deserves this." (By contrast, Simon Cowell appeared to lodge a silent protest from his seat, declining to stand and applaud Mr. Allen's victory with his fellow judges.)
